0.user_question: If $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ then find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that $\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{v} = 2$ and $\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.$

ost_step.2: From the condition $\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{v} = 2,$ we get $x + y + z = 2.$
ost_step.3: Using the cross product property, $(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{v})_{ijk} = (\mathbf{a}_j\mathbf{v}_k-\mathbf{a}_k\mathbf{v}_j)$, so expanding out $\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{v}$ yields $$\begin{pmatrix} i & j & k \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \\ x & y & z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x - z \\ -(y -z) \\ y - x \end{pmatrix}.$$Setting this equal to $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$, we obtain $$x - z = 1,\quad - (y - z) = -2,\quad y - x = 1.$$From here it follows immediately that $\{x=2/2,y=-2/2,z=3/2\} = \{1,-1,3/2\}$. Checking our solution against both conditions, everything checks out! Thus, $\boxed{\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\-1\\3/2 \end{pmatrix}}.$

1.subquestion: Write down the dot product condition involving vectors $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{v}$.

subanswer.text: The dot product condition states that $\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{v} = (1)(v_1) + (1)(v_2) + (1)(v_3) = v_1 + v_2 + v_3 = 2,$ where $v_1, v_2,$ and $v_3$ represent the components of $\mathbf{v}$. The answer is $v_1 + v_2 + v_3 = 2.$
